commits.commitMessage:
SWIMDM-2969 - Update install package and hexagon version for SDX65

Update the install script for native SDX65 build.
1) Add zlib1g-dev package to fix a apss build error caused by
"zlib.h " not found.
2) Add the installation script for hexagon version 8.5.09 needed
by SDX65 LE1.2.

Change-Id: I3dcc3f04e893e8a93b8e8c95bd5a1a9387b4fb88
Signed-off-by: Kenneth Yeung <kyeung@sierrawireless.com>
commits.subject: SWIMDM-2969 - Update install package and hexagon version for SDX65

comments.message: Just FYI, there's been some discussion to remove these scripts from the repo and support the CPComposer method only, but no reason to hold out this fix in the meantime.  Lgtm.
I would hope we can have more than one way to build as on ubuntu 18.04 we can actually build the code natively without cpcomposer for both sdx55 and sdx65.

I think that's fair.  CP team will only actively maintain, document, or debug the composer solution, but it's not essential that we remove the alternative, if other teams want to maintain it.

Note that this will include any custom tools added by CP team though.  If we add a tool, it will get added to the composer method, and teams relying on the native build will have to figure it out.  It's not going to be a high frequency occurrence, but it's likely to occur.

commits.commitMessage:
SWIMDM-2737 - Add docker-compose system for MDM9X06 LE2.1.2 system

Replace mdm9x06le20 build support with mdm9x06le212 support.  The
LE 2.1.2 system includes Yocto 3.1 for the Linux build, requiring
an updated base image.

Setup for the new environment remains the same:
    >> python3 cpcomposer.py setup mdm9x06

This continues to generate two environments, which are renamed to
match the system:
    >> mdm9x06le212_apss_build
    >> mdm9x06le212_build

Other build instructions remain the same for the mdm9x06 system.

Change-Id: I7c12fdf847bc5d95ed818a1f4c2a5362bfefcc06
commits.subject: SWIMDM-2737 - Add docker-compose system for MDM9X06 LE2.1.2 system

comments.message:
This change seems correct and logical to me.

I was not able to find the test evidence of the compilation in -2737. Since CI does not test this, I suspect docker compose build on WP77 after this change was tested locally?
Description of patch set 4 set to "fix missing 8.5.07 hexagon during docker image generation"

Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)

This change is ready for review.

commits.commitMessage:
EM92 needs hexagon 8.5.7

This only affect developer building natively and legacy docker

```
ack 8.5.07 modem_proc/build/ms/build_cfg.xml
      <hexagon_rtos_release>  8.5.07  </hexagon_rtos_release>
```
Ref: https://gerrit.legato/c/tools/cp-utils/+/80825
(cpcomposer support, already merged)

Change-Id: I234049675b0b1a0c5f0626fd78a455300d6f8e0c
commits.subject: EM92 needs hexagon 8.5.7

comments.message:
Hi Stoyan and Ryan,

May I have your comment on this change? I will create a jira ticket if it is considered worth checking in.

Thanks

Hi Calvin, the change looks fine but the plan of record was to deprecate these dockerfiles and replace with support of the CP Composer method in full.

Is there any concern with migrating to that solution?  There are a variety of options to continue to support these files, but the preference is to have everyone migrate to the same system where support will be more active.

No concern really. I have already migrated to CP Composer.

Let me abandon this change

Hi Ryan,

As a developer, legacy docker gives me more flexibility. I understand supporting multiple solution is not feasible but I thought firmware team can maintain their own solution as "legacy".
Either way, I am OK with not updating legacy docker.
Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.

commits.commitMessage:
SWIMDM-2773 - hexagon 8.5.07 for SDX65 and removing SCONS max jobs env

Adding Hexagon 8.5.07 to the SDX65 docker-compose file.

The SCONS_MAX_NUM_JOBS=2 ENV has also been removed from all .env files

Change-Id: I8ab421bda304de299f74a43ff4bcb53bfac08aaa
commits.subject: SWIMDM-2773 - hexagon 8.5.07 for SDX65 and removing SCONS max jobs env

comments.message: We'll want to trim some of the unused compilers soon, but this seems like a good step to accomodate everyone, while it's changing rapidly still.
Agreed. We will also have to remove the volumes from the host, either manually as a general cleanup at some point, or update the tool to remove unused volumes automatically.

commits.commitMessage:
SWIMDM-2591 - multi-platform build support via docker-compose

Centralizing docker bring up for compilation on developer build
machine using docker-compose. All images are reused from the
registry.legato. A wrapper tool "cpcomposer.py" is used to
call any of the docker-compose commands, it can install
shortcuts in ~/.bashrc to simplify compilation or entry into
the docker containers

Yocto Builders:
Products that use Yocto require the use of a separate builder, for example
sdx55_apss_build instead of sdx55_build. This is due to different
requirements for Yocto. To build Yocto/Apss do the following:

    cd into the folder of the Makefile
    >> <platform>_apss_build
    >> make image_src

    Upon exit the shell is still the container.
    ONLY METHOD 2 (below) IS SUPPORTED.

cpcomposer.py:
Cellular Platform's script for creating docker containers using
docker-compose. The containers are used for building all
supported Cellular Platform platforms. All images used for the
containers are obtained from registry.legato, although this is
configurable in each <platform>/docker-compose.yaml file

Requirements:
* python3
* docker-compose, installed by sudo pip3 install docker-compose
* access to registry.legato

Setup:
cd into the directory that contains the cpcomposer.py script
then run:
    >> python3 cpcomposer.py setup <list of platforms>

Example for individual platform:
    >> python3 cpcomposer.py setup sdx65

Multiple platforms:
    >> python3 cpcomposer.py setup sdx65 sdx55 mdm9x28 mdm9x06

Use "--bashrc" to install bash shortcuts in the ~/.bashrc file.
Compiling the platforms would then be executed using the shortcuts, or
directly from their mktarg.sh if the environment variable
SIERRA_USE_CPCOMPOSER is set to yes (export SIERRA_USE_CPCOMPOSER=yes).

"source ~/.bashrc" is required after each setup to reapply the
shortcuts to existing shells if --bashrc option was used.

If --bashrc is not used then need to source individual environment
scripts for each new shell

Example: source cp-utils/build/compose/sdx65_envauto.sh

There are three supported methods of compiling

Method 0:
This method is the intended standard method and is integration into
mktarg.sh.
With SIERRA_USE_CPCOMPOSER=yes environment set:

    >> ./mktarg.sh <target>

Method 1:
Executing ./mktarg.sh <target> directly without entering the
container first. Upon completion the host shell is retained.

Example sdx65:
    cd into the directory containing ./mktarg.sh

    >> sdx65_build ./mktarg.sh mpss

    This will start the container and run ./mktarg.sh mpss

Method 2:
Enter the docker container's shell and compile within the container

Example sdx65:
cd into the root of the sdx65 workspace. The root directory is the
one containing the .repo folder. This is needed as a mktarg.sh
relies on sourcing scripts from ../sierra/ which is in the root of
of the workspace as it will be shown as

>> cd ~/ws/sdx65le10
>> sdx65_build

This will now enter the container and all shells commands following
this will be executed within the container. The container can
be identified by the shell "<user>@<builder_name>:<pwd>$"

>> <user>@sdx65_build:/ws/sdx65le10$ cd sdx65
>> <user>@sdx65_build:/ws/sdx65le10$ ./mktarg.sh mpss

When this completes the shell is still that of the container until
'exit' is called to return back to the host shell. The containers
are limited and do not have a lot of useful programs so "Method 1"
is the recommended method.

The shortcuts rely on the path of cpcomposer.py. If this path changes
then setup must be rerun to update the shortcuts

The compilation methods are only available after running the setup for the
desired platforms

    >> python3 cpcomposer.py setup <list of platforms>

Remember to "source ~/.bashrc" after each setup with --bashrc in case new
shortcuts are installed

Change-Id: I8f9a3e4f866f6cfed989f701738e2c830dfc341b
commits.subject: SWIMDM-2591 - multi-platform build support via docker-compose

comments.message:
I can build WP77 successfully with your patch.

I just have 2 minor comments.

Works great on SDX65! Documentation is also very clear.

I am trying on some other platforms now too.
Can we execute this automatically instead of interrupting the user?

We can. One idea floating around is that we will use a separate setup script that will setup all the required tools on the development machine (docker, python3, docker-compose, registry access, etc). Then cpcomposer.py would only be expected to work on systems that have the standardized setup.
Please also make sure that fetchcert.sh is +x mode.
It was already +x on my filesystem, not sure why Gerrit does not allow. Tried now with git add --chmod=+x but still don't see any changes.

Thanks for the review and the trial run. I've addressed the comments. The latest patchset will not install the global bashrc shortcuts unless --bashrc is specified. This is done in preparation of linking cpcomposer.py directly in mktarg.sh. I will push an AMSS change to demo this on SDX65 soon.
Not sure why sdx55_build ./mktarg.sh UEFI fails to build, but native ./mktarg.sh UEFI can build successfully. Not sure if this composer py can hep to address that.
Missed the gcc-4.8 requirement for UEFI. The updated sdx55/docker-compose.yaml has it now.
Still working on getting the image_src/yocto compilation images setup. Having issues with the yocto images, but for sdx55 using the SDX65 image seems to work fine.
Patchset 9 should be able to compile yocto. All my problems seem to have been workspace contamination for previous host builds.

I verified the docker compose compilation of RC76 on my build machine and it works well. The only point I'd like to make is that compilation needs to be done in three steps:

mdm9x28tx10_build ./mktarg.sh all (will fail on apss but build everything prior to apss)
mdm9x28tx10_apss_build ./mktarg.sh apss (builds only apss)
mdm9x28tx10_apss_build ./mktarg.sh common (builds the CWE-s)

Maybe there is an easier way, but it would be good to document that.

https://gerrit.legato/c/external/qct/mdm9x07/+/78912 ties everything in with the mktarg.sh for tx, and will allow you to run "./mktarg.sh <target>" directly. Only limitation is the "all" build (current CP docker files have the same limitation) The apss builds are using a different image, and so we can't run them all in a single one. 

Running ./mktrag.sh all will not be supported on all targets (sdx65 will work as apss builds on same image as the rest). This will be documented in a confluence page.

We need to give the docker container read/write access to the "/run/user" directory to have all the UT cases pass. UT campaigns such as ut_fm_modem were designed to store temp files in this directory.

I got all the UT cases to pass by adding the line:
            - /run/user:/run/user:rw
Maybe it is better to state: "also can install" since it does that only when --bashrc option is provided.
It might be useful to add [--bashrc] here ti illustrate the option.

With the mktarg.sh integration I suspect the majority of users will never call cpcomposer.py manually and would not be using --bashrc. The bashrc is really for debuging development and is well documented with cpcomposer.py setup -h for example
Should we add this automatically to bashrc?
This would be another topic/ticket as the idea is that the cp-utils/install.sh setups the requirements for the cpcomposer, including exporting this variable. For now it is a manual setup.
Would it be clearer to add "If --bashrc is used, ..."
Do we need to add "for each new shell environment"
Some minor comments. I am building yocto for EM9190 and WP76 using <platform>_build smoothly for the first time. Ongoing build...

I can build and run EM9190 (product branch) image successfully using docker composer the first time!!!
I added a few minor comments but looks good.
LGTM. Minor comment and a question is added.

Just FYI, if make image_src is encountering edk2 failure, just cd to edk2 folder and run
1. git clean -xfd 
2. git reset --hard 
then it solves my edk2 build problem.

These 2 commands had fixed many corrupted workspace problem.

Just a question: Would it be possible to define these variables in docker-compose.yaml for the SDX65 platform instead? That way all docker configuration will be in the same file.
Similar comment for the other platforms.
These variables can be in the .yaml, however it would mean they are copied and pasted for each builder within the .yaml file. Using dedicated .env files reduces the duplication.

I gave this a try by doing an incremental build on RC76 and it worked very seamlessly.

Something potentially helpful for debugging purposes is to have either mktarg.sh or cpcomposer.py print a debug statement when it enters and exits the docker container (this would also be a good reminder for remembering to set SIERRA_USE_CPCOMPOSER=yes).
lgtm, let's conclude on Emery's question in the meeting today, as either something to do now or defer, but otherwise looks ready to go.  Thanks for the significant documentation.

commits.commitMessage:
SWIMDM-2073 - Install python 2.7 compatible pytest version

pip versions before 9.0 did not support the python_requires field.
This causes pip to install the latest version of pytest, which has
dropped support for python 2.7. The last version of pytest to support
python 2.7 is pytest 4.6.x.

Failure in installing pytest will now also cause the script to exit
with failure.

Change-Id: Ie5a54bc28bb2a0f8bd1fc5d9ec4dc78d40accf6c
commits.subject: SWIMDM-2073 - Install python 2.7 compatible pytest version

commits.commitMessage:
SWIMDM-2545 - Docker development environment for LeTP tests

Added cp_sanity.Dockerfile and support in build_docker.sh in cp/utils.

When building the cp_sanity.Dockerfile using build_docker.sh, a
working directory is a required input argument. build_docker.sh
then clones the FWINT LETP repo with cp tests checked out into
this directory before building the docker image. The
build_letp_tests command is added to the host systems
~/.bashrc file, this can be used to run the docker image
with no necessary arguments (LETP directory is mounted automatically).

Resolves: SWIMDM-2545
Change-Id: I8b02f7a8000532513a64af7e942beb54eb5091c7
commits.subject: SWIMDM-2545 - Docker development environment for LeTP tests

comments.message: Looks good.  Some comments added inline.

Could we make this consistent with other projects by just defining "letp_tests" in the list above, and adding -w <WORKSPACE> (for example) as a mandatory option for letp_tests?

Sure, I think the goal was to differentiate between building the LETP docker image and the other FW docker images so developers understand that they work in different ways. The approach you mention might be enough in this respect.
Maybe this file should be in /docker/?
It looks good to me for now, and we'll need to sort out how it fits with the compose strategy coming up.  But just needs a rebase for now, for me.
Thanks Ryan, hopefully this is a good starting point to eventually move over to the docker compose. Rebase should be done now.

good catch.

we may need to clean up the =build_docker.sh by removing the $LE_VER usage

Hi Emery,

It works fine when providing an argument to ./build_docker.sh. Not sure why we need this change.
also, it removes support for LE11

Hi Farzad, thank you for your comment.

Do you mean that you are able to supply an LE argument to the build_docker script? If so, I still think this change is needed because it doesn't match use documentation and multiple LE versions are not supported by the script (according to its own -h response). 

We can also update build_docker to officially support multiple LE versions, however maybe @Ryan would be able to comment on weather we are looking to support both LE versions or not.

Thanks

Correct, build_docker requires an update to show options with -h.
FW team still needs to have an option to build different LEs to provide support for SDX55's issues.

Thanks
Alternatively we can have a Docker which supports all LEs. It reduces the number of images users need to build and also reduces storage usage in host machines.
seems to me that sdx55le12.Dockerfile is dedicated used for sdx55 le12 ( and le14) build only, so actually we don't need to define LE setting inside the sdx55le12.Docker file
sorry, please ignore my comment.  Actually, we do need the original fix as the LE is used to identify LE1.1 and LE1.2/LE1.4 build.

I think you're probably right.  @Emery, how about:
1) Add a build argument for sdx55le14 system.  Whether it's unique or not, it's confusing to invoke le12 to build le14.
2) Update sdx55le12 dockerfile to sdx55leXX.Dockerfile
3) Update build_docker.sh to feed the Dockerfile the appropriate version based on the system name provided as an argument, and support all three images, adding the appropriate name in the build alias.

I don't think that's too much overhead, and shouldn't conflict with what Stoyan's doing for longer term evolution, but of course everyone's welcome to chime in.

Sounds good, is the RVCT version the same between LE12/LE14? 

I will give this a try and check to make sure that the tools are properly installed.

another comment on the build/install/build_docker.sh

Hi Farzad,  what you're doing matches instructions we've used in the past, but it seems like the FARM does this a bit differently:
http://cgit-legato/docker-images.git/tree/tools/python/Dockerfile

Could you take a quick look at that, if not already, and just provide reply if you think this method has any specific advantages, or if either solution is fine?  Eventually we'd like to converge these more, so it would be good to note if this solution is replaceable with the FARM solution.

Hi Ryan,

I am not a fan of downloading files from external servers. The best solution is downloading deb files from our local server. This way we avoid issues with URL changes. But I guess maintaining local server is a hassle.

Instead I prefer to download from Ubuntu's repos. Also, to make sure everyone installing the same version, it is better to provide version during installation,
apt install  python3=3.5.1-3


Please let me know you prefer FARM method or the method mentioned above.

2. It will be better to post the generated image to register.legato so that all team members can use it directly without need to spending a lots of time to build the local docker image.  So far I still see some issues on my local docker image which may due to my local setup.  Seems to me this docker file can not be used correctly in some cases ( e.g. logname command does not work on my box.)

Thanks, I think that's fine.  I do think downloading from "python.org" is about as safe and reliable as possible, but the main advantage of FARM method is unused by us, which is that they really only need it to work once, since the container is re-used from a registry.  We can look closer at convergence another time, I just wanted to get some trace of the factors here.  LGTM.

commits.commitMessage:
SWIMDM-2501 - Add a Dockerfile for all CP platforms

Adds a Dockerfile for each CP supported platform, with minor updates
to handle the new platforms.  The general Dockerfile design aligns
with the existing SDX55 image.

Each system functions independantly, which leaves room for
improvement with possibilities to leverage both built docker images
from the Sierra docker registry, and commonality across build machine
requirements.  These improvements will be deferred to a future
implementation.

The sdx65le10 tools are also updated throughout for the latest LLVM
and Hexagon requirements.

Change-Id: I5ce737d897322e10234aea2dfc5356c019e76dd7
commits.subject: SWIMDM-2501 - Add a Dockerfile for all CP platforms

comments.message: This doesn't need review, just demonstrating some changes in build_docker and the dockerfiles that are working for mdm9x28le212 system build.

Looks good to me and is a useful extension of docker build for different CP platforms. I have added some small comments for potential improvements.

---

A general comment regarding the multitude of Docker files added is that there is a lot of code re-use and it looks like that there is a lot new in different files, but in fact they are mostly the same. Perhaps if this approach is adopted, we can in the future have some layered approach to create docker images so that common configuration is captured on a low layer and changes for individual platforms captured in a higher layer (I suppose that should be possible.)

Lastly, I suppose ./mktarg.sh script changes to utilize these images will be in a different review?
Couple comments after debugging with Stoyan
Do we need this in LE Dockerfile?
Yes, I think we're going to use this for TX too.
Is this a TODO comment? If so, maybe add a note that this is future work
Yes, this note is intended to describe the future work required.  If we stick with this method, we probably need a cleaner way of checking than one at a time.

We can also add echo of the user environment in this and below cases too. Please see above for an example:

"""echo "\
#!/usr/bin/env bash
...
"""
Will look into this for a future update

This needs to be done as _not_ sudo, since we'll be copying files here after dropping down.
(Stoyan figured this out)
Found when building this dockerfile on U20

Since we are no longer specifying LE version as an argument, this conditional might not be needed. 

It also seems to cause a bug where RVCT is not installed at all (directory /pkg/qct/software/arm doesn't exist when build finishes)
I'll look into this as a follow-up.  I think we might still need to support multiple variants for awhile, with le12 and le14 being active, so I haven't removed this yet.
I think we can formalize this and the sdx65 dockerfile might be needed by the team first. It also might be good to have some readme/quick guide so that work instruction doc can link to it.

commits.commitMessage:
SWIMDM-1104 - Update install scripts

Issues:
(1) There's no script for setting up env variables.
(2) install.sh script did not correctly install libraries for support of
32 bit emulation on Ubuntu 14.04
(3) Hexagon tool version needed for SDX55 compilation was not present
(4) ARM and LM License file pointing to hard coded IP address instead of
a ARM server name in original swienv.sh

Solutions:
(1) Added swienv.sh script in the same folder as the install.sh. This script
sets environment variables needed for building on all platforms. It can be
invoked using 'source swienv.sh'
(2) Removed non-existent libraries so that the ones that are needed
can be installed correctly.
(3) Added support for Hexagon 83.04 tool needed for SDX55
(4) Pointed ARM and LM license file to cnhkg-arm01 rather than hard-coded
IP address

Change-Id: Ic5b9ac430fef7ff5ddae26f8fb40862af60259a9
commits.subject: SWIMDM-1104 - Update install scripts

This can be deleted, I used to need this on really old Ubuntu (10.04 or 12.04, but haven't enabled it for 14.04)

comments.message: That's only because we haven't made one yet.  Why not make one?  Then this is redundant for the others.
So should we remove this change?
removed. I made a helper function for SDX55
Question for others. Why not get the username from $USER and then let the user enter their password as opposed to storing your password in a plain text file?

>echo "Enter your Sierra username?"
>read S_USER
>
>echo
>echo "Enter your Sierra password"
>read -s S_PASS
>
>sudo mount -t cifs //jasmine2/Projects-1 /mnt/j2p1 -o >username=$S_USER,password=$S_PASS,domain="SIERRAWIRELESS"

or something of the kind seems to work fine
I have no idea which is more considered more secure.  The protected .smbcreds has been our documented process as long as I can remember.

As an example, my mount line is as follows:
sudo mount -t cifs -o domain=SIERRAWIRELESS,username=avirdi,uid=1000,sec=ntlm //jasmine2/projects-1 /mnt/j2p1

The mount program will ask me for the password. I don't like having my password stored in plain text. :)
I'm guessing the script should stop and wait for password entry, so you don't have to read it in the script.
Sam's method could be safer than storing your password in a text file.
... and just because we've done something a certain way, doesn't mean it's right. ;)
Anyways, you don't have to update this here. I typically would ensure I use the script so that I don't have to create the .smbcreds file. I also don't automatically mount my drives on startup, so that also makes a difference...
Yes, I think Ian advocated for this method. The 9x30 work instructions doc mentions this as the preferred method.

I like Paul's take here - I will still have CIFS prompt for user login (in case the host name != user name) but I will let cifs itself ask for a password instead of storing it in either plain text or a shell variable (and then passing it to CIFS)

Keep in mind that this script supplements instructions, it doesn't replace them.  I'd suggest that you update the Work Instructions in Confluence to make this recommendation too, if we think this is an improvement towards security.
Yup - I think I'll let others chime in on this.

The 9x30 instructions:
"Warning: Perform this section at your own risk. It is fairly trivial for someone to access this file by simply booting your computer from DVD and accessing the file system as root without any credentials. Making this file readable only for root is only slightly more secure than leaving your windows password on a sticky note on your computer."

So I vote we change it in this script.

Ok, I'll update to the script asking for user input. 

I will also change it to mount the network drive as read-only, since that seems a bit safer.

5 seconds seems way too long. I'm sure I sometimes type sooner than that.
Did you try removing this? -> "not sure if required"?

Considering this is only done roughly once per chipset, it probably is ok if we leave it in. 
Typo 'required'
Let's change it to 1 second then.

I suppose this assumes ~/bin is in the $PATH? I didn't specifically see if PATH is being updated in this script.

It would probably be good to verify we are using SWI's version of repo. Maybe a new ticket, Ryan?

.profile adds this to the path.

># set PATH so it includes user's private bin if it exists
>if [ -d "$HOME/bin" ] ; then
>    PATH="$HOME/bin:$PATH"
>fi

the above are the relevant lines. I'm not 100% sure if subsequent versions of Ubuntu will have the same line in .profile, but for now I think we can leave it as is.

Is this required for 9x05? I can't recall when QTI introduced this but I kind of recall QTI having this in their instructions prior to 9x15, which was the first Linux based chipset.
So I'm not sure if "required for android" is the only reason.
not required for 9X05, I can't find any reference to it in the 9x05 documents
The whole thing is run as sudo - is this required?
Maybe it's not required in one case, but life seems a lot simpler if we're all using the same shell.
I agree - but I rather not change the system shell from what it expects (dash) to something else  (bash) unless there is a hard reason for it.
I agree, that's why I was providing information on how to change it, rather than changing it.  This update actually goes farther towards forching the change than before, except in your case :)

I see your point Ryan - 

I spoke to Maggie and Brad and they seem to think that we should force bash. I think that any script that starts with #!/bin/bash should evoke bash - but obviously there is something I am missing.

I agree with Ryan on this one.
We should be careful imposing this type of change. However, that being said, even we probably use bash for all scripts.... We'd only get in trouble if QTI used some feature of dash specifically.

the file .profile.sh is sourced on login and that's the file that adds repo to the default path.

default .profile can be seen in /etc/skel/.profile - I think it only runs on login

That's outside the scope of this script isn't it?  There's no update to .profile here, so that might be the whole reason repo wasn't found.  If it was found with "which repo", then the path is already found.  If it wasn't found, because the path wasn't set, then the check isn't accurate.

I'm a little hazy here since I am not a unix expert - but this is my understanding of the problem.

from .profile we can see the following:

># set PATH so it includes user's private bin if it exists
>if [ -d "$HOME/bin" ] ; then
>    PATH="$HOME/bin:$PATH"
>fi

the issue is, the first time we run this script we probably don't have a $HOME/bin - so we won't add $HOME/bin to the path.

That means if we install repo, then run repo - it won't be found (the shell does not know it needs to search $HOME/bin)

for any shell we are logged into - we can obviously update the path variable, but the update would be lost if we close that shell.

The only permanent solution to add the $HOME/bin to the path is to either logout and login (or reboot), which would run .profile. Now any subsequent shells would take the updated value of $PATH, which now includes $HOME/bin - so now we can use repo.

I think we can assume .profile already exists and $HOME/bin already exists.  We're assuming it does, when we look for repo already.  We can state this in the README, if we need to.  Basically, this script shouldn't be the first thing you ever run on a new machine, I guess.

Hi Ryan -

I guess my rational was that I wanted a script that would work all the time (including the case the user has nothing in $HOME/bin)

This leads to two cases:

Person A has something installed in $HOME/bin - repo would work right away - we would be asking them to do an extra reset.

Person B has nothing installed in $HOME/bin - their install would be successful - but repo won't run (until they login/logout or reset). Person B would somehow have to be informed that they need to do a reset - or add $HOME/bin to the current execution shell each time they want to run repo (until they do a reset)

I guess to avoid B, I went with asking everyone to reset, this hides some .profile "semantics" 

I will remove the prompt since you don't think it belongs - but I still think it's a good idea to warn the user they they need to reset or logout/login if they want to use repo and it's the first time they added something to $HOME/bin?

If we're warning people they need to reset, we should at least base it on whether or not we had to create the ~/bin directory when setting up repo.  I think the attention to this step is all a bit unnecessary and over-complicated for this script - the user still isn't getting a complete development environment from this script - I'm not sure "repo" even falls into the intended domain of this script, since it isn't a build tool.  The new user still can't access gerrit at this point - do we add that too?  (I hope not).  This was to install build tools.  Most users will already have repo, just to get access to this script in the first place.
Just wondering why you don't use $USER from the environment variable?
Just for the sake of flexibility - I can change to $USER if you want.

I would prefer typing one less thing. :) So using $USER.
Or you could put: "Push enter to use default: $USER" This way I'd only need to hit enter by confirming that $USER == my username.

Hi Paul, since this script runs as root 

$USER == root

Is it OK if I leave it as is? I can't think of a decent workaround in my head right now

Can you try $SUDO_USER?
When I type "sudo env", that's the only place my username shows up.

I suppose this script is run under sudo, so the Linux password is not needed?
Should we say: "please enter your Windows password"?

I just realized this would be installed as root... 

I'm not sure if this is a problem as everyone has execute permission.

I verified repo does work - but if there is any trepidation I'll just remove this functionality - as Ryan said this script might be going further than it was intended to.

commits.commitMessage:
SWIMDM-263 - Add scripts for whitespace, tabs, and line-ending cleanup

These simple shell scripts are intended to assist developers in sanity checking
that changes meet basic coding standard:

  1. whitespace: removes trailing whitespace
  2. tabs2spaces: replaces tab "\t" characters with two spaces
  3. line-endings: replaces dos-style line-endings with unix style
  4. clean: runs all three of the previous scripts

Each script supports directory or file input, and optional arguments for
recursion and automatic backup.  The file is modified in place.

Note that this script is not always suitable with third party code, since
we do not generally cleanup third party code outside the scope of our
patches.  Additional usage information is provided in Help menus (-h)
and in cp-utils/review/README.txt

Change-Id: Ib8f4e10ab3c3a087501e78c882e3e8d404b002ab
commits.subject: SWIMDM-263 - Add scripts for whitespace, tabs, and line-ending cleanup

These scripts are added to simplify installation of build tools used
in various CP firmware projects.  This initial revision is a first
draft, tested on a few machines, and essentially dedicated for execution
in North America based on use of Sierra servers in Canada.  The SDX55
installation uses Shenzhen servers, if SITE is provided as SHZ.

    a file.

commits.commitMessage:
SWIMDM-257 - Add a python script to copy JIRA tickets

jira_copy.py copies a JIRA ticket to a destination JIRA project.  The input
ticket is not modified, and the new ticket retains the original description
with a preface added at the top describing where the ticket was copied from.

The new ticket subject line is prefixed with the original JIRA project name,
and a link is added to both tickets.

The intent is for this script to ease porting activity by replicating the
original ticket quickly.

Change-Id: Iba079cc4fd095138e4f798b94118028d0b775c9f
commits.subject: SWIMDM-257 - Add a python script to copy JIRA tickets
